awd_titl_txt: CREWS: Chemical Resonance Excitation Wavelength Selection for Label-Free DNA Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop a multiwavelength surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) method for determining genomic mutations within specific genes related to antimicrobial resistance. The PI has published convincing preliminary results on extracting relevant information related to the composition of DNA strands from the measured SERS spectra. The ability to rapidly determining the genomic mutations within specific genes related to antimicrobial resistance would have a significant societal impact.mThe project will provide scientific training for students at graduate and undergraduate levels across several multidisciplinary fields, exposing them to advanced photonics, nanoscale fabrication, surface chemistry, and medical diagnostics. 

The goal of this project is to develop the chemical resonance excitation wavelength selection (CREWS) method for determining genomic mutations within specific genes related to antimicrobial resistance (AMR). The proposed platform employs multiple excitation wavelengths to maximize the amount of data acquired from DNA using Raman spectroscopy, and uses advanced signal processing techniques to identify mutations within genes responsible for causing AMR. This technique provides an alternative approach to genomic mutation detection without the need for DNA sequencing, in which quick and efficient label-free detection of single point mutations in DNA strands can be performed.

por.por_cntn:
The dramatically increasing rates of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) on the global scale is a growing problem due to the frequent prescribing of antibiotics, leading to significant costs and poor treatment plans as patients develop resistance to antibiotics. Thus, the ability to quickly and accurately determine a patient?s resistance to specific antibiotics is crucial to addressing the growing problems of AMR. Here, we proposed an affordable, portable system for the detection of AMR using a novel approach via a surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) technique that performs label-free characterization of DNA by exploiting multiple degrees of freedom. Although advances in next generation sequencing are promising, the ability to quickly determine AMR from extracted DNA via sequencing at a low cost is still out of reach. We developed an alternative genomic mutation detection approach that utilizes the high specificity and sensitivity of SERS, in which the interaction of photons with strands of DNA provides unique molecular information about the composition of DNA extracted from genomic material. We directly apply this method for label-free identification of genomic mutations in genes responsible for AMR, with potential to expand this technique to detecting genomic mutations for medical diagnostics.

The overarching goal of this project is to develop the chemical resonance excitation wavelength selection (CREWS) method for determining genomic mutations within specific genes related to AMR. The proposed platform employs multiple excitation wavelengths to maximize the amount of data acquired from DNA using Raman spectroscopy, and uses advanced signal processing techniques to identify mutations within genes responsible for causing AMR. This technique provides an alternative approach to genomic mutation detection without the need for DNA sequencing, in which quick and efficient label-free detection of single point mutations in DNA strands can be performed. To reach this goal, we enhanced understanding of the chemical enhancement (CE) resonance effect of nucleic acids and implement a functional composition detector for single-stranded DNA (ssDNA). We learned that the strong correlation between specific properties of the SERS signal and concentration of relevant DNA bases can be leveraged for molecular composition analysis. In particular, in our developed method we calibrated the detector with multiple measurements using known ssDNA compositions, and tested it with an unknown test samples. We also extended the research to examine the CE effect of nucleic acids interacting with various metal substrates (i.e., copper, gold, silver, aluminum) and characterized their CE effects. Using the nanorod morphology, the metal substrates were able to support both CE and electromagnetic enhancement (EM) effects, further improving the fidelity of the measured data. Furthermore, we observed that the charge transfer effect happening during the SERS process is metal dependent, thus allowing us to utilize an additional degree of freedom to affect the signal. We also carried out a study of EM and CE degrees of freedom mechanisms to serve as different probes for SERS and to develop a Machine Learning (ML) based methods to enable higher prediction/sensing ability. Specifically, we experimentally showed that silver, gold and aluminum substrates lead to different CE effects and sensitivity levels when it comes to ssDNA composition detection. Therefore, in order to include all necessary features from SERS signals of ssDNA on different metals, we explored an ML fusion sensor model. Our results indicated that this sensor model yielded improved high base length sensitivity of 0.1% with a 1.2% quantification accuracy. On a fundamental level, we realized the importance of SERS signals in reading the difference between ssDNA base permutations, from our experiments and simulations? results.

The ability to develop a highly complex optical system with important clinical applications has potential to impact the world on a global scale. The carried out research, which integrates components from several areas of science, engineering, and medicine, have profound societal impact as swift detection of AMR of patients would become a reality. The necessary information provided by the CREWS DNA detection method enables doctors to properly prescribe antibiotics to their patients without trial and error, cutting costs for the hospitals and ensuring proper treatment. Additionally, the project provided scientific training for students at graduate and undergraduate levels across several multidisciplinary fields, exposing them to advanced photonics, nanoscale fabrication, surface chemistry, and medical diagnostics. We continue to be committed to outreach, education and collaborative efforts with San Diego middle and high schools. Through our relationships with the Sweetwater, Preuss, and High Tech High Schools, we successfully engaged students of diverse ethnicity, gender and economic backgrounds in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM). We continue the ongoing RET, REU, and COSMOS programs.  For this project, we developed new mechanisms, as well as use traditional means, for data dissemination using our experience from working in an interdisciplinary and collaborative environment.
